p: The respiratory epithelium is the primary site of host-pathogen encounter in the respiratory tract and the first line of defence against infection [ 121, 122]. The respiratory epithelium restricts bacterial attachment through mucociliary clearance and maintenance of cell-cell junctions, which restricts access to bacterial receptors [ 123]. There is evidence that primary viral infections disrupt the respiratory epithelium leading to decreased bacterial clearance. In-vitro studies have shown that cells infected with RV, RSV, adenovirus and influenza led to impairment of mucociliary function and consequent decreased clearance of bacteria including S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae [ 124â€“ 127].
